sentences.sentence: Was Cheng Jingye internally chastised or encouraged for his comments to Australia last week?

Alexander Downer, a polite diplomat, suggests the comments misread domestic public opinion ("China needs a better grasp of democracies like Australia", May 3).But does China care if it rubs its neighbours the wrong way?
China is a purchaser of our materials for which it has other suppliers.
Conversely, Australia has a primary interest in China firing up its production capacity to return to growth.
To rebalance, Australia must innovate and diversify.

More Atlassians, energy technologies and medical and educational advancements, for example.If this crisis teaches us one thing, it's that we can continue to play to our natural comparative advantages.
We can also work hard to create new relationships as well.

The century is still young.Matt RockeDrouin, VicIt's Downer whodoesn't get ChinaAlexander Downer tells us that Chinese ambassador Cheng Jingye "doesn't understand" Australia.Mr Downer obviously doesn't understand the Chinese mindset and the importance of "face", the self-esteem and status someone has and which would be seriously diminished if they surrendered to impolite demands to allow foreigners to swarm into their country to investigate - and perhaps find evidence of - laxity in the management of the COVID-19 outbreak.A more nuanced - and thoughtful - approach to get Chinese assistance would have been to congratulate them on their success in controlling the virus and asking them if they had any useful advice for us from their own investigation.

It's called diplomacy, Mr Downer.Bill DeaneChapman, ACTMisunderstandingon both sidesAs one of a handful of Australians who have worked with China for more than 30 years, I have a very good understanding of how they think.

Culturally they are very different from us, and have been programmed by their government to think in a certain way and to believe certain things.Much of what I read about China seems to be written by people who have never been to the place.

Alexander Downer is one of the few exceptions - he clearly understands the country and its people.Scott Morrison is entirely correct in requesting that we be allowed to discover the details of the coronavirus outbreak, and any normal country would agree to help the world do so.

That said, China is not normal, and under President Xi Jinping, there is no doubt that China has regressed.We would be well advised to temper our language and try to negotiate an outcome; indeed the Chinese would also be well served to stop their ambassadors from threatening Australia - none of this sits well with Australians - we are also a proud country.
Thirty years of dealing with the Chinese tells me that this is simply how they behave, and we should not be surprised, we should adapt.Ross JacksonBelrose, NSW

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.
documents.inputText: Was Cheng Jingye internally chastised or encouraged for his comments to Australia last week? Alexander Downer, a polite diplomat, suggests the comments misread domestic public opinion ("China needs a better grasp of democracies like Australia", May 3).But does China care if it rubs its neighbours the wrong way? China is a purchaser of our materials for which it has other suppliers. Conversely, Australia has a primary interest in China firing up its production capacity to return to growth. To rebalance, Australia must innovate and diversify. More Atlassians, energy technologies and medical and educational advancements, for example.If this crisis teaches us one thing, it's that we can continue to play to our natural comparative advantages. We can also work hard to create new relationships as well. The century is still young.Matt RockeDrouin, VicIt's Downer whodoesn't get ChinaAlexander Downer tells us that Chinese ambassador Cheng Jingye "doesn't understand" Australia.Mr Downer obviously doesn't understand the Chinese mindset and the importance of "face", the self-esteem and status someone has and which would be seriously diminished if they surrendered to impolite demands to allow foreigners to swarm into their country to investigate - and perhaps find evidence of - laxity in the management of the COVID-19 outbreak.A more nuanced - and thoughtful - approach to get Chinese assistance would have been to congratulate them on their success in controlling the virus and asking them if they had any useful advice for us from their own investigation. It's called diplomacy, Mr Downer.Bill DeaneChapman, ACTMisunderstandingon both sidesAs one of a handful of Australians who have worked with China for more than 30 years, I have a very good understanding of how they think. Culturally they are very different from us, and have been programmed by their government to think in a certain way and to believe certain things.Much of what I read about China seems to be written by people who have never been to the place. Alexander Downer is one of the few exceptions - he clearly understands the country and its people.Scott Morrison is entirely correct in requesting that we be allowed to discover the details of the coronavirus outbreak, and any normal country would agree to help the world do so. That said, China is not normal, and under President Xi Jinping, there is no doubt that China has regressed.We would be well advised to temper our language and try to negotiate an outcome; indeed the Chinese would also be well served to stop their ambassadors from threatening Australia - none of this sits well with Australians - we are also a proud country. Thirty years of dealing with the Chinese tells me that this is simply how they behave, and we should not be surprised, we should adapt.Ross JacksonBelrose, NSW
